Strive is the Guilty Gear of fighting games.
Wait...
Ok, Guilty Gear Strive is the Guilty Gear of the Guilty Gear franchise. Yeah, that sounds better.

It is definitely worth playing even if you don't dump in hundreds of hours. It's incredible having so many wild offensive moves (like Venom playing billiards in a fight), as well as so many defensive options at your disposal, it makes the game so much more dynamic than just "I block everything, then I do one of two strings, then I repeat". The best part is that these usually aren't as hard to use as you'd imagine, there are plenty of easier characters to play with, and the core, universal mechanics are very simple to use. Of course, the high level gameplay is a lot deeper and richer, and so far, getting into this game seriously has been very rewarding, especially with good tutorial missions.

Though, I gotta say, the game's publisher apparently doesn't know what regional pricing is, so it's very expensive for a Brazilian like me. If you're not BIG into fighting games, you should probably wait for a discount. For as great of a game as it is, it's nothing I couldn't have waited for.

I also got a handful of DLCs, also at a discount, but that's just because I wanna make a fighting game of my own and wanted to experiment, you people shouldn't worry about DLCs unless there's something that really catches you (do your research before buying!)

I've been playing this series since XX on the PS2 (That must mean I'm good at the game, right? ...Right?) which was the Street Fighter 2, of Guilty Gear, getting numerous updates and revisions. But my love for this franchise didn't truly set in until my cousin and I were at Best Buy in the early 00s, around Christmas time, and we noticed Guilty Gear X2 Midnight Carnival Reload on Xbox and decided to pick it up, myself having a bit of prior understanding with the series, and assuming it to be an actual sequel. We must have put dozens of hours in to that game. But this review isn't about that original PS2 release, or the Xbox update.


As I said, I've been playing Guilty Gear on and off for 20+ years. I have a fascination with fighting games (especially the ones with intriguing characters, storylines and lore, like MK or GG), even if I don't excel at any of them, I love sinking time in to them. I played Xrd and Rev on PS4 a bunch, and Strive being the next evolution of the change in formula that started with Xrd, I can confidently say this game is great, and worth your time. There are a couple minor nitpicks, like how Asuka, or "That Man" 's storyline was dropped or should I say shifted in favor of  another character becoming ‚ÄúThat man‚Äù and the UI on the character select screen which has always been innovative, is rather basic in Strive, but those are nitpicks and doesn't take away from the core experience. I can't speak much to the online, as I've only played a bit. For a series like Guilty Gear, as aforementioned I'm not good enough to play at high levels, or against players who have hundreds if not thousands of hours in to each one, but for the offline play, the AI will still push you to try. You better learn your roman cancels and your overdrives because they're going to bring it. The way the characters just pop against the gorgeous 2.5D artwork and character designs, which the series has always been notable for, but here it really does stand out.

To close this review off, Guilty Gear is a series created by a Japanese game director and musician who from his love of music, decided to create a fighting game to show off his appreciation for the genre, and created a great franchise underneath it all.

I'm a mentally stable Zato player and I can say this, GGST and the whole series has me by the balls and I love every moment of this game. I love getting zoned out from characters Axl, Venmon, and Dizzy. I love getting DPed by Sol, Ky, Sin, Dizzy, and Leo. I love getting out speed and mixed up by Chipp, I-No, Millia, and Gio. And more so characters having really unique gimmicks like Faust, Asuka, Nago, and Happy Chaos. But the big bodies are amazing like Pot, Bedman, and Goldlewis. It's all the more fun when you play one of the characters that's been consistently bottom tier in all the games(for the most part).

In all seriousness this game is genuinely one of the best fighting games out there, the gameplay is incredibly smooth and the unique mechanics make this game stand out very much from both Burst and Roman Cancel allowing for more offense and defense. Almost every single character is unique and so different from one another that they all stand out so much from one another, not only from a gameplay perspective but also character design. All the characters are so over the top with unbelievably crazy backstory set in a very interesting world. The whole world running off of magic set in the far future, giant state size zepplins, Japan got nuked again, pirate crew with jets and airships shaped like sea creatures, a weird dimension called The Backyard that contains everything from the Past, Present, and Future. The craziness of the characters and the world is all the better with the god tier Rock n Roll album like OST, I'm convinced there's no other fighting game out with an OST that can be compared to something similar like GGST OST. One of the few OST that I actually added to my playlist and I scream my lungs out too like Crawl, Subhuman, Hellfire, and more.

Of course the games has it flaws like its servers being iffy at times and the story mode being a five hour long movie with mediocre animation and truth be told the story not making sense at times, but that's not to say that the where it lacks in those departments, it makes up for everything else. GGST stands out like like a kid having really dumb ideas and then making them work in ways that it shouldn't and I love it, the series is incredibly fun and different, the gameplay is addictive and overall just an amazing game. It's def worth picking up and playing even if you don't like fighting games, this one is worth a try.

All but one took me multiple tries, and I had to look up how to do the tension mission because the timer was too short to build up by mashing buttons (the strat that worked was just... sprinting forward???). Instead of letting you try to perform the task until you succeed X number of times, most all tutorials give you a short amount of time to accomplish the tutorial tasks, and you fail the tutorial if you don't. as a casual fg enjoyer and someone who has slight coordination problems, this game is a quite good.
at the other hand, as someone who is a huge lover of guilty gear's themes and lore, this game feels like a downgrade. on first sight, it felt like a toned down guilty gear, and while gameplay wise it took away insta kills which I think of as an important element in gg, and dumbed down some characters, strive also had its improvements, mostly the roman cancel, but reminder that I am a VERY CASUAL fg player, so my view on gameplay can be taken with a grain of salt or even disregarded.
now as for the themes and the lore I'll just make a very quick not-well-thought-out explanation. the story is kind of mediocre, at least where I stopped. I am willing to finish it but... I just don't really want to, I will update this review in the future if I finish it. the story itself is basically carried by the new antagonist happy chaos. and somewhat by Jack-O' and Sol's relationship, which is my favorite part atm, probably being biased. the animation is... not awful but... this game definitely needed to released year later, I in general have not much problems with animation (I'm a winx club fan) but holy shit some parts are actually really bad, and when you compare it to xrd, you won't get too good results for a game released like 4 years after the last major update (that wasn't rollback) of the previous.
now the themes, as an avid enjoyer of the aesthetic of previous games, ESPECIALLY OVERTURE, I think... strive kinda lack. it has chains. but not enough chains. it has belts but NOT ENOUGH belts. Dizzy having no belts at all, you could say "oh but she is queen now" but I do not think it would be a good excuse, she can still look more modest while still integrating belts into it even if just one. now the menu: holy shit I hated it SINCE THE MOMENT I SAW IT.
